Literature Review: FLASH radiotherapy (FLASH-RT) represents a groundbreaking advancement in the field of radiobiology, offering a novel approach to cancer treatment that could significantly enhance the therapeutic index. This innovative technique utilizes ultrahigh-dose rates, delivering radiation in extremely short durations (<500 ms), which has been shown to spare normal tissues while maintaining or even enhancing tumor control. This phenomenon, known as the FLASH effect, has sparked considerable interest and research efforts aimed at understanding its underlying mechanisms and potential applications in clinical oncology. The exploration of FLASH-RT's differential impact on tumor versus normal tissues is crucial for its development and optimization as a therapeutic modality. Several studies have begun to elucidate the biological and physical principles that may account for the FLASH effect. For instance, it has been hypothesized that the rapid delivery of radiation may alter the oxygen consumption dynamics within tissues, leading to a transient state of hypoxia that protects normal tissues from radiation damage while still allowing for effective tumor cell killing (Montay-Gruel et al., 2017). This hypothesis is supported by experimental evidence demonstrating that the protective effect of FLASH-RT is diminished in the presence of oxygen, suggesting a critical role for oxygen tension in mediating the FLASH effect (Vozenin et al., 2019). Another proposed mechanism involves the differential activation of DNA damage response pathways in normal versus tumor cells following FLASH-RT. It has been suggested that the ultrahigh dose rates may induce a unique pattern of DNA damage that is more efficiently repaired in normal cells, thereby sparing them from the detrimental effects of radiation (Favaudon et al., 2014). This concept is further supported by studies showing that FLASH-RT results in reduced levels of persistent DNA damage and apoptosis in normal tissues compared to conventional radiotherapy (Bourhis et al., 2019). The potential of FLASH-RT to revolutionize cancer treatment is also underscored by its ability to overcome some of the limitations associated with conventional radiotherapy, such as the risk of long-term side effects and the development of radiation resistance in tumor cells. Preclinical studies have demonstrated that FLASH-RT can achieve equivalent or superior tumor control with significantly reduced toxicity to surrounding normal tissues, highlighting its potential to improve patient outcomes (Diffenderfer et al., 2020). Moreover, the application of FLASH-RT in various cancer models has shown promising results, including enhanced tumor regression and prolonged survival, without the associated increase in normal tissue complications (Schuler et al., 2017). Despite these encouraging findings, several challenges remain in the translation of FLASH-RT from the laboratory to the clinic. These include the development of reliable and scalable technologies for delivering ultrahigh-dose rate radiation, the establishment of standardized protocols for treatment planning and delivery, and the need for comprehensive clinical trials to evaluate the safety and efficacy of FLASH-RT in human patients (Wilson et al., 2020). Additionally, further research is required to fully understand the biological mechanisms underlying the FLASH effect and to identify the optimal conditions for its application in different cancer types and stages. In conclusion, FLASH-RT holds immense promise as a transformative approach to cancer treatment, offering the potential to significantly improve the therapeutic index by sparing normal tissues while effectively targeting tumors. As research in this field continues to advance, it is anticipated that FLASH-RT will play an increasingly important role in the future of oncology, providing new hope for patients with cancer.
